Notes: Found on a decaying aspen tree near Whisper Creek. Vibrant orange color, even in shade.
Highly toxic. Traditionally used as a dye. Found on a Douglas Fir at high elevation.
Forms distinctive map-like patterns on granite boulders in the alpine zone. Very slow growing.
Bright red apothecia resemble tiny matchsticks. Growing on a rotting log in a damp hollow.
Single-point attachment to rock face. Dark brown, almost black, color. Specimen was quite brittle.
Contains cephalodia, which look like dark warts on the upper surface. Indicates nitrogen fixation.
Areoles are angular and fit together like pavement. Found on a sun-exposed cliff face.
Edible and was a traditional food source for indigenous peoples. Drapes from pine branches.
Unusual for this altitude, found near a saline hot spring, mimicking a coastal environment.
Lobes are hollow and inflated. Common on a variety of tree species throughout the lower valley.
Resembles lung tissue, used in traditional medicine. Sensitive to air pollution, a good bioindicator.
Hangs in long tassels from older trees. Central cord is elastic when wet, a key identifier.
